titleStmt.title: Cobwebs to Catch Flies: or, Dialogues in Short Sentences, Adapted to Children from the Age of Three to Eight Years.
titleStmt.author: Lady Ellenor Fenn

sourceDesc.p:
XXX
Cobwebs to Catch Flies: or, Dialogues in Short Sentences, Adapted to Children from the Age of Three to Eight Years. Lady Ellenor Fenn John Marshall No. 4, Aldermary Church-Yard, Bow-Lane, Cheapside, London 1794 CHL0007

docTitle.titlePart: or, Dialogues in Short Sentences Adapted to Children from the Age of Three to Eight Years.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Our cat can get a rat: Can she not?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Yes, she can; but she was bit by the old rat one day.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Ah! my Kit! why did you try to get the old rat?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: One day the dog bit our cat; he bit her jaw.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: May the cat get on my bed?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Yes, she may.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: May she lie by me?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Yes; go, get up; go to the boy.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Kit! Kit! Kit! you may get on the bed.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Now you are up. Why do you say mew? Why do you say pur? You may lie by me, Cat. See her joy as I pat her ear! Why do you get off the bed? Why do you beg to be let out?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: To go to her kit.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Has she a kit? Why do you go to the kit? Is she to go?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Yes; let her go now.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Nowget up; it is six.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: O, me! is it six?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Yes, it is; and the dew is off.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I see the sun. It is fit for me to go out.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Now it is; but by ten it may be hot. So get up now.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: May I go to-day, and buy my top?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Yes, you may.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
A peg-top? Sam has a peg-top. He has let me get his. One day he did. I met Tom one day, and he had a top so big! I can hop as far as Tom can. Tom has a bat too? and Tom is but of my age.
Let us buy a cup and a mug for Bet. And let us get a gun for Sam. And a pot and an urn for Bet. An ant has bit my leg; see how red it is! May I get a bag for Bet?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Can you pay for it?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: O, no; but you can pay for all. May the dog go?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Yes, he may go.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I see him: may I let him in?

sp.speaker: First Boy
sp.p: I See a man! The man has a dog. The man is got in. The dog is not got in. He can not get in.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Do not cry; you will see the manby-and-by. Dog! why do you cry?

sp.speaker: Secon Boy
sp.p: I can not see.

sp.speaker: First Boy
sp.p: You are too low.--get up.

sp.speaker: Second Boy
sp.p: I can not get up.

sp.speaker: First Boy
sp.p: Try;--now you are up.

sp.speaker: Second Boy
sp.p: I see the cow.

sp.speaker: First Boy
sp.p: I see two. I see the red cow; and I see the dun cow.

sp.speaker: Second Boy
sp.p: I see a hog. Pig! Pig! why do you run?

sp.speaker: First Boy
sp.p: Now I see ten. Why do you all run? Now let us go off.

sp.speaker: Second Boy
sp.p: You can not see me.

sp.speaker: First Boy
sp.p: You are hid.

sp.speaker: Second Boy
sp.p: I see you. Can you not see me?

sp.speaker: First Boy
sp.p: O, now I can get up.

sp.speaker: Second Boy
sp.p: No, I can run; you can not get me.

sp.speaker: First Boy
sp.p: Yes, I can.

sp.speaker: Second Boy
sp.p: Let us go to Tom.

sp.speaker: First Boy
sp.p: We may not go out.

sp.speaker: Second Boy
sp.p: I can get out.

sp.speaker: First Boy
sp.p: So can I; but do not go yet.

sp.speaker: Second Boy
sp.p: Why may not we go yet?

p.ref: Do as you are bid, and do not ask why, is the law for a boy.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I Saw a rat; and I saw the dog try to get it.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: And did he get it?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: No; but the cat did.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: My cat?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: No; it was the old cat.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: How did she get it? She can not run.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: No, it is not the way:--she was hid--the rat ran out; and pop! She got him.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: A dog can run.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Yes; but a cat is sly.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: The kit can not get a rat.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: No, she can not yet; but she can get a fly. I saw her get a fly.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I Love the dog. Do not you?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Yes, sure.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Wag! do you love me?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: You see he does; he wags his tail. When he wags his tail, he says, I love you.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Does his tail tell me so?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Yes; it says, I love you; I love you; pray love me.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: When we go out, he wags his tail: what does his tail say then?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Pray let me go; I wish to go with you.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I love to have him go with me.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Here is a cake for you.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Nice cake! See the dog! how he wags his tail now! Why do you wags your tail? Why do you look so? Why does he wags his tail so much? Why does he look at me?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: To beg for some cake. His tail says I love you; you have a cake, and I have none; will you not be good to me? Will you not give some of your cake to your poor dog?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
Poor dog! do you want some cake? take a bit. Here! I hold it to him, but he does not take a
bit.--take some. O! he has got it all--he was not to take all. Fie, Wag! to take all. Now I have none left. You are rude, Wag.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: He did stay some time.--Here, I will give you a plum-cake.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Now you are to have none, Wag. You are to have none of this cake; you were rude.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: He did not know that he was not to take all. He can not know all that you say.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Well, you may have a bit of this. I will take a bit off, and give it to him.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Do so. You are a good boy. We must be kind to all. We must give to them who want.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Why do you ask for more?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: He has not had a meal to-day. He had not a bit till now. You had had food.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
I hope he will have meat at noon. I will ask cook to give him a bone; and he may have some milk; and he can have some bran. Cook will boil them for him. Poor dog! he can not ask as we can, so I will ask for him. Wag, I wish
you could talk. Why does he bark at poor men?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: When he sees a man whom he does not know, then he says Who are you?--who are you?--why do you come?--what do you do here?--I am at home--I must tell the folk--I must tell that you are here--I will call our folk to look at you. Come out man; come out maid:--see who this is.--Bow, wow, wow, wow!

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Does the dog say all that? Why does he stop, as soon as the folk come out?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p:
He is so wise as to know that
he need bark no more then. If he mean to call them out, he will stop when they are come out.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Wag, why do you gape when you are hot? Can you tell me why he does so?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: To cool himself.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I Do not love pigs.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.p:
A pig is not so nice as a fowl;
yet we must feed the pigs. Pigs must eat as well as boys. Poor pigs want food.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Do they cry for food? I hear them cry.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.p: They cry to me for food; in the way they can call, they call,--Pray feed me; pray feed me! do, pray feed me now!

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: What do you give them?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.p: This pail full of milk. Will you not like to see them? They will be so glad!

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: How they jump! how they run to the gate! Why do they run so?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.p: They are glad to see me. They know me. I feed them when they want food; and you see they love me.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I like to see them so glad. I like to see a pig fed; but I love a lamb; may I not love a lamb more than I do a pig?

p.ref: Yes; but you must be good to all.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
My aunt has a tame lamb;
I love to give him milk; once I saw a fawn. I do not mean in a park, but I saw a tame fawn; the old doe was dead, so we fed the fawn at home. We kept him a long time, but he bit off the buds.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.p: Have you seen a goat?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Yes; he has not wool; he has hair.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.p: Now you may go with me. We will go and feed the cows.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Why is one duck by itself?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.p:
The duck sits; she has a nest
just by. I must feed her: she will not go far from her nest. The rest can get food. You may give her some corn; we will get some for her. Come.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I like to feed the poor duck.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: What a nice doll! I like this; pray may I have this? I wish to have a wax doll.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: You must then take care to keep her cool, else you will melt her face; and she must be kept dry, or this nice pink on her face will be lost.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p:
What a neat coat! I like a blue silk. And her hat! I love a doll in a hat. What sort of a cap have you got, miss! but a poor one; but it is not much seen. She has some soil on the neck. I can rub it off I see. No, that will not do; I must not wet her skin. What sort of a foot have you? O! a nice one: and a neat silk shoe: a blue knot too; well, that is what I like; to suit her coat. I am fond of blue
too. Now, miss if I have you home with me, then I am to be your maid; to wait on you. Will not that be nice? I will take care of you, and keep you so neat! and I will work for you; you can not sew, nor hem; and I will read to you in my new book; and I will take you out with me when you are good. You shall sit by me near the tree, on a low seat, fit for you. I wish you to walk? Can not I make you walk? so--step on--step on--see how my new doll can walk!

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: You will pull off her legs, my dear.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p:
Now if I had a pin to pin this
sash back. Stay, I can tie it. O me! see! here is a bag for her work! who has seen the like? a bag for her work! I must have this doll--if you like it, I mean.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: You must then work for her. You will have much to do. To make and mend all that your doll will want to wear. Will not you wish her in the shop? I fear that you will; you who are so fond of play.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: Work for my doll will not tire me.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Take it then.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: You are so good! pray let me hughug you. I must kiss you too, my dear doll for joy.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: I Like this cap; but it will not keep on. Why will it not keep on?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.p: It is too big for you, miss.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: It is off; it will fall off.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.p: You had best lay it down, miss.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: I like to have it; I will put it on.

p.ref: My dear! lay it down when you are bid to do so; do not wait to be made to do well.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: I will not, mamma. Smith, I will be good. Pray may I look in this box?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: You see it is shut now; you may see it by-and-by.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: I will not hurt the lock.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: You must not try.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: May I play with your muff?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: You may.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: What is this made of?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Fur; and fur is skin with the hair on.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: It is like puss; how soft it is!--How warm it is when I hold it to my nose! it is like wool.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Now come and kiss me; I am sure you will be good to John; go and play with him.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: Do you stay all day? do you stay till John is in bed?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Yes; till you are both in bed. Now go.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: Pray let me get my work-bag first. May I get my work-bag?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Why do you want it?

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: I want some silk out of it; that I may work a ball for John.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What does he want? What does that mean?

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: It is his way to say pray.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: And what does he wish?

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: To have your fan: But he will tear it.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Can you take care of it?

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: O! yes; I can show it to him.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Take it; and let him see it.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p:
Now sit by me. Pray set him down by me. Look! no; you must not have it. I must keep it in my hand. You can not hold it.
Here is a boy. See! he runs to get that bird. O fie! do not get the bird. No! you must not put the bird in a cagecage. Let the bird flyfly; let him sing; and let him help to make a nest. Do not hurt the poor bird. You must be good and kind. You must not vex the bird. Here is a girl. Look at her pink coat. Here is her foot. She has a blueblue shoe. She is at play with the boy. Miss! you must be good. You must tell the boy to be good; that we may love him. All good folk will love him if he be good; not else.
Now let us turn the fan. Now we will look at this side. Here is a nice pink. This is a rose. That is a fly.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Now John will walk. Ring the bell. Go and walk with your maid.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: Am I to go?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: As you like.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: I like best to stay; but John says with his hand, pray go. I will go then! dear boy! I will go with you.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Good girl!

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: John! you must love me; I wish to stay here, and you hear that I may stay.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: Take hold of him and lead him out. You will meet the maid at the door.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I Will have a gun. No, I will have this doh. May I not have both?

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: You may have both.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Let me see, here is a goat. Do look at his face; how like it is to a goat! Here is a ball; and a lamb with wool on it, just like my lamb that I feed at home. And here is a cock; can you crow? Crow, and tell us that it is time to rise. Can you not? What a tail he has! A fine tail! No, I will not have that, for his tail will soon be off. Some part of it is come off now.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: You must not pull. You do harm.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I did not pull hard.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: You are a long time.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
O, here is a horse! I like this horse. I like his long tail. You shall not have your tail cut--no, nor your ears: but you can not feel. Come, Sir, walk, and trot. Do you move well? I will rub you down, and give you oatsoats and hay, and chop straw for you. I will be good to you, not whip you much,--no more than just to say,--Now go on;--nor spur you, nor gall your poor skin; no, nor let the hair rub off. So--you set your tail well; but if you did not, Tom must not nick you; no, nor yet dock your poor tail; you will
want it to keep the flies from you when it is hot. I see poor Crop toss his head all day; he does it it to keep the flies from him; but it is all in vain, he can not keep them off. I will be good to you; I will tend and feed you; and I will not ride too hard, and hurt your feet; nor trot on hard road, so as to make you fall and cut your knees; but I will pat your neck when I get up, and I will make you know me; so that you will turn your head, and seem to like to have me get on your back. At night you must have a warm bed. When I have rode you in the day, I will see that you have good corn, and hayhay, and straw; and Tom must wash the hot sand out of
your poor feet, so that they may not ache, and make you grow lame.

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p: I can not but give you the horse, as you seem to plan so well for him; I hope you will be good and kind to all things.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I do not care now for the lamb, nor for the--

sp.speaker: Mamma
sp.p:
My dear, I would have you know your own mind; if you get the trick to like now this, now that, and now you know not what, it will do you harm all your life.--So it is that boys and men spend too much; so it is that they act like fools. I would give you
all the toys in the shop, if it were for your good to have them: the horse you have got; now take some one else; take the gun, do you like the gun?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I do; I thank you, mamma. I will keep the horse; and I will give the gun to Jack. O! my dear horse, how I love you!

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: There is a field full of nettles.

sp.speaker: Papa
sp.p: No, not so, it is hemp.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: What is that for, papa?

sp.speaker: Papa
sp.p: To make cloth of; the stalk has a tough peel on it, and that peel is what they make thread of. The thread they weave, and make strong cloth.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I want to know all the trees; pray what leaf is this?

sp.speaker: Papa
sp.p:
That is an Oak; that bush is May; we call it too White-Thorn; it blooms late in May; its fruit are called Haws; so we call it Haw-Thorn. The birds eat the fruit. That is Black-Thorn; that blooms soon in the spring; it has a white bloom, and has then few or no leaves. The
fruit is a sloe. They are like a small blue plum; but so sour that you can not eat them.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: What is this?

sp.speaker: Papa
sp.p: Wild Rose; its fruit are Hips; they are kept, and we take them for coughs. That is broom; it has a bloom like a pea in shape, but it is yellow.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: There is a bunch of it in bloom.

sp.speaker: Papa
sp.p: No; that is Furze, such as you see on heaths. Feel this; Broom does not prick like this.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I will keep a leaf of each to show to James.

sp.speaker: Papa
sp.p: You may put them in a book, and write what I have told you.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I will get all sorts of plants; and I will mark by each the name, the place, the bloom, the time when it blows, and the use which is made of it.

sp.speaker: First Girl
sp.p: My doll's quilt is chintz. What is this?

sp.speaker: Second Girl
sp.p: Old point.

sp.speaker: First Girl
sp.p: Let us take the Doll up.

sp.speaker: Second Girl
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: First Girl
sp.p: Where are her clothes?

sp.speaker: Second Girl
sp.p: Here they are; some in this chest, and some hang in the press!

sp.speaker: First Girl
sp.p: Bless me! what a nice press! I have a chest at home, in my doll's house; but I have no press.

sp.speaker: Second Girl
sp.p: Here are her shiftshift and coat; those shoes are her best, do not put them on; take these.

sp.speaker: First Girl
sp.p: What gown does she put on?

sp.speaker: Second Girl
sp.p: Her white one. I will take it out, whilst you lace her stays.

sp.speaker: First Girl
sp.p: What is her best cloackcloak?

sp.speaker: Second Girl
sp.p: White; with a neat blond lace round it.

sp.speaker: First Girl
sp.p: Mine has a muff; has your doll a muff?

sp.speaker: Second Girl
sp.p: No, she has not; my aunt says she will teach me to do chain stitch; and then I am to work on one.

sp.speaker: First Girl
sp.p: What is her best dress?

sp.speaker: Second Girl
sp.p: You shall see them all? there is the gown which I like best.

sp.speaker: First Girl
sp.p: Why do you like it best?

sp.speaker: Second Girl
sp.p:
It is my dear mamma's work; see
how neat it is; and there is a green silk.

sp.speaker: First Girl
sp.p: My doll's best coat is brown, with a stripe of blue; and she has a white, wrought with a moss rose, a pink, and a large bunch of leaves: that was her best, but it is just worn out now; she must leave it off soon.

sp.speaker: Second Girl
sp.p: What does she wear it so long?

sp.speaker: First Girl
sp.p: I had a crown to buy her a piece of silk; as I went in the coach with my aunt to buy it, we met a poor child who had no clothes, but the worst rags which you can think.

sp.speaker: Second Girl
sp.p:
And you gave it to her.
My doll should wear her old gown for a long time, for the sake of such use to put my crown.

p.ref: I had more joy in that, than I could have had in my doll's new gowngown. Dolls can not feel the want of clothes.

sp.speaker: Second Girl
sp.p: Now let us go down stairs.

sense.def: A cat is a furry animal that has a long tail and sharp claws. Cats are often kept as pets.

figure.figDesc: A gray rat standing on all-fours.

sense.def: A rat is an animal which has a long tail and looks like a large mouse.
A dog is a very common four-legged animal that is often kept by people as a pet or to guard or hunt. There are many different breeds of dog.
A bed is a piece of furniture that you lie on when you sleep.
Your jaw is the lower part of your face below your mouth. The movement of your jaw is sometimes considered to express a particular emotion.
Joy is a feeling of great happiness.
Your ears are the two parts of your body, one on each side of your head, with which you hear sounds.
Dew is small drops of water that form on the ground and other surfaces outdoors during the night.
The sun is the ball of fire in the sky that the Earth goes around, and that gives us heat and light.
If you hop, you move along by jumping on one foot.
A bat is a specially shaped piece of wood that is used for hitting the ball in baseball, softball, or cricket.
A cup is a small, round container that you drink from.
A mug is a large, deep cup with straight sides and a handle, used for hot drinks.
A gun is a weapon from which bullets or other things are fired.
A pot is a deep round container, often used for cooking stews, soups, and other food.
a vessel that is typically an ornamental vase on a pedestal and that is used for various purposes, such as preserving ashes after cremation.
Ants are small crawling insects that live in large groups.
A person or animal's legs are the long parts of their body that they use to stand on.
A bag is a strong container with one or two handles, used to carry things in.
Something that is red is the color of blood, fire, or roses.
When you pay an amount of money to someone, you give it to them because you are buying something from them or because you owe it to them.
When you cry, tears come from your eyes, usually because you are unhappy or hurt.
A cow is a large animal, often black and white, that is kept on farms for its milk.
A pig is a pink or black animal with short legs and a curly tail. Pigs are often kept on farms for their meat, which is called pork, ham, or bacon.
If you hide or if you hide yourself, you go somewhere where you cannot easily be seen or found.
When you run, you move more quickly than when you walk, for example because you are in a hurry to get somewhere, or for exercise.
Something that is old has existed for a long time and is no longer young.
A fly is a small insect with two wings. There are many kinds of flies, and the most common are black in color.
When a dog wags its tail, it repeatedly waves its tail from side to side.
The tail of an animal, bird, or fish is the part extending beyond the end of its body.
A cake is a sweet food made by baking a mixture of flour, eggs, sugar, in an oven. Cakes are often served for birthdays.
A plum is a small, sweet fruit with a smooth purple, red, or yellow skin and a pit in the middle.
A meal is serving of food you have when people sit down and eat, usually at a regular time.
Food is what people and animals eat.
Meat is solid food taken from an animal that people cook and eat.
Milk is the white liquid produced by cows, goats, and some other animals, which people drink and use to make butter, cheese, and yogurt.
Bran is the outer skin of grain that is left when the grain has been used to make flour.
When you boil food, or when it boils, it is cooked in boiling water.
When you talk, you use spoken language to express your thoughts, ideas, or feelings.
Someone's home is the house,apartment, or place where they live.
When a dog barks, it makes a short, loud noise, once or several times.
A fowl is a bird, especially one that can be eaten as food, such as a duck or a chicken.
A pail is a bucket, usually made of metal or wood.
If you jump, you bend your knees, push against the ground with your feet, and spring quickly upward into the air.
A lamb is a young sheep.
A fawn is a very young deer.
A park is a public area of land with grass and trees, usually in a town, where people go in order to relax, play, and enjoy themselves.
A doe is an adult female deer.
A goat is a farm animal or a wild animal that is about the size of a sheep. Goats have horns, and hairs on their chin which resemble a beard.
Wool is the hair that grows on sheep and on some other animals, often used to make things like clothes, blankets, and carpets.
Hair is the threads that grown on your head, or cover the body of an animal such as a dog, or make up a horse's mane and tail.
A duck is a common water bird with short legs, a short neck, and a large flat beak.
A bird or other creature's nest is the home that it makes to settle down and lay its eggs in.
Corn is a tall plant which produces long vegetables covered with yellow seeds. It can also be used to refer to the yellow seeds.
A doll is a child's toy which looks like a small person or baby.
Your face is the front part of your head from your chin to the top of your forehead, where your mouth, eyes, nose, and other features are.
A coat is a piece of clothing with long sleeves which you wear over your other clothes when you go outside.
Something that is blue is the color of the sky on a sunny day or the ocean.
Silk is a type of smooth fine cloth.
A hat is a head covering, often with a brim around it, which is usually worn outdoors to give protection from the weather.
A close-fitting covering for the head, usually of soft supple material.
Your neck is the part of your body which joins your head to the rest of your body.
Your feet are the parts of your body that are at the ends of your legs, and that you stand on. You have a left foot and a right foot.
Shoes are objects which you wear on your feet. They cover most of your foot and you wear them over socks or stockings.
If you tie a knot in a piece of string, rope, cloth, or other material, you pass one end or part of it through a loop and pull it tight.
When you sew something such as clothes, you make them or repair them by joining pieces of cloth together by passing thread through them with a needle.

A book is a number of pieces of paper, usually with words printed on them, which are fastened together and fixed inside a cover of stronger paper or cardboard. Books contain information, stories, or poetry, for example.
A tree is a tall plant that has a hard trunk, branches, and leaves.
Pins are very small thin pointed pieces of metal. They are used in sewing to fasten pieces of material or hold them in a certain way.
A sash is a long piece of cloth which people wear around their waist or over one shoulder, especially with formal or official clothes.
When you hug someone, you put your arms around them and hold them tightly, for example because you like them or are pleased to see them.
A box is a square or rectangular container with hard or stiff sides. Boxes often have lids.
The lock on something such as a door or a drawer is the device which is used to keep it shut and prevent other people from opening it. Locks are opened with a key.
A ball is a round or oval object that is used in games such as tennis, baseball, football, basketball, and soccer.
A wish is a desire or strong feeling that you want to have something or do something. If you wish for something, you want it to happen.
If you tear paper, cloth, or another material, you pull it into two pieces or you pull it so that a hole appears in it.
Your hands are the parts of your body at the end of your arms. Each hand has four fingers and a thumb.
A bird is a creature with feathers and wings. Female birds lay eggs. Most birds can fly.
A cage is a structure of wire or metal bars in which birds or animals are kept.
A rose is a flower, often with a pleasant smell, which grows on a bush with stems that have sharp points called thorns on them.
A bell is a metal object shaped like a cup that makes a ringing sound and is used to give a signal or to attract people's attention.
A door is a piece of wood, glass, or metal, which is moved to open and close the entrance to a building, room, closet, or vehicle.
A rooster is an adult male chicken. In British English, a rooster can also be called a cock.
XXXA horse is a large animal which people can ride. Some horses are used for pulling plows and carts.
Oats are a cereal crop or its grains, used for making cookies or a food called oatmeal, or for feeding animals.
Hay is grass which has been cut and dried so that it can be used to feed animals.
Straw consists of the dried, yellowish stalks from crops such as wheat or barley, often used for animal food or bedding.
Your head is the top part of your body, which has your eyes, mouth, nose, and brain in it.
A road is a long piece of hard ground that is built between two places so that people can travel easily from one place to the other.
Your knee is the place where your leg bends.
A person's or animal's back is the part of their body between their head and their legs that is on the opposite side to their chest and stomach.
The night is the part of each day when the sun has set and it is dark outside, especially the time when people are sleeping.
Day is the part of each day when it is light outside, usually when you are up and doing things.
You refer to someone's mind when talking about their thoughts or brain.
A toy is an object that children play with, for example, a doll or a model car.
A field is an area of grass, for example, in a park or on a farm. A field is also an area of land on which a crop is grown.
The stalk of a flower, leaf, or fruit is the thin part that joins it to the plant or tree.
A thread is a long very thin piece of a material such as cotton, nylon, or silk, especially one that is used in sewing.
A bush is a large plant which is smaller than a tree and has a lot of branches.
A fruit is something which grows on a tree or bush and which contains seeds or a pit covered by a substance that you can eat.
Spring is the season between winter and summer when the weather becomes warmer and plants start to grow again.
Peas are round green seeds that grow in long thin cases and are eaten as a vegetable.
Something that is yellow is the color of lemons, butter, or the middle part of an egg.
When you write, you use something such as a pen or pencil to produce words, letters, or numbers.
A plant is a living thing that grows in the earth and has a stem, leaves, and roots. Plants can also be kept in pots or vases.
Your heart is the organ in your chest that pumps the blood around your body. You can also refer to someone's heart when you are talking about their deep feelings and beliefs.
Clothes are the things that people wear, such as shirts, coats, pants, and dresses.
A chest is a large, heavy box used for storing things.
A garment usually consisting of a one-piece bodice and skirt.
A cloak is a long, loose, sleeveless piece of clothing which people used to wear over their other clothes when they went out.
Green is the color of grass or leaves.
Something that is brown is the color of dirt or of wood.
Pink is the color between red and white, such as the color of a pig.
A coach is an enclosed vehicle with four wheels which is pulled by horses, and in which people used to travel.
Ragged or tattered clothing.
Stairs are a set of steps inside a building which go from one floor to another.
